Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Story:
I was halfway through my shift as a subway operator when my phone buzzed with a message from my stepdad: “Can you call? Your mom’s not feeling well.” I glanced at the control panel, my heart tightening. I knew they expected me to check in, to be the bridge that kept our patchwork family steady. I always tried to ask if everything was okay at home, to show I cared, even if it felt awkward sometimes.

But just as I reached for my phone during a lull, a piercing alarm blared from the console—a critical brake system malfunction. My training kicked in: I had to report it immediately, stop the train, and ensure everyone’s safety. The passengers depended on me to keep them safe and on time. My hands shook as I hovered between the emergency radio and my phone. My family needed me, but so did the hundred strangers in my care. The weight of both worlds pressed down, and I felt split in two, unable to be what everyone needed at the same time.
